qas.question: What does the MP3 compression take advantage of?
What is the limitation in human hearing referred to as?
Who was the physicist to report that a tone could be rendered inaudible.
When were audio curves described by Richard Ehmer?
The initial work was aimed at determining critical ratios and what else?

context: The MP3 lossy audio data compression algorithm takes advantage of a <a0_0>perceptual limitation<a0_0/> of human hearing called <a1_0>auditory masking<a1_0/>. In 1894, the American physicist <a2_0>Alfred M. Mayer<a2_0/> reported that a tone could be rendered inaudible by another tone of lower frequency. In <a3_0>1959<a3_0/>, Richard Ehmer described a complete set of auditory curves regarding this phenomenon. Ernst Terhardt et al. created an algorithm describing auditory masking with high accuracy. This work added to a variety of reports from authors dating back to Fletcher, and to the work that initially determined critical ratios and <a4_0>critical bandwidths<a4_0/>.
